bibl.title: Letter to Henry Rose Carter, February 17, 1915

div1.p: The writer discusses fish stocks in local reservoirs.

div1.head: Letter to Henry Rose Carter, February 17, 1915
div1.opener:
FRANK S. WASHBURN,
PRESIDENT
J. W. WORTHINGTON, VICE-PRESIDENT
F. H. CHAMBERLAIN, GEN'L. MGR.
THOS. W. MARTIN, GEN. COUNSEL
WILEY ALFORD, SEC'Y & TREAS.
ALABAMA POWER COMPANY
BIRMINGHAM, ALABAMA.
February 17th, 1915.
Dr. H. R. Carter, Sr. Surgeon,
U.S. Public Health Service,
Baltimore, Md.
Dear Dr. Carter:
div1.p:
I intended to reply to yours of the 30th sometime
ago, but I have given practically all of my time recently to
the Court proceedings at Columbiana. I am sure that you will
be interested to know that we won our first suit. General
Gorgas' testimony was of great assistance to us; in fact,
I fully believe that it was his testimony which won the suit.
The suit was one of L. D. Hand against the Company and was
one of the worst suits which we had to contend with.

I spent three days with General Gorgas going over
conditions around the Lock 12 reservoir and, as we have had
several weeks of dry weather here, conditions were very sim-
ilar, as far as breeding places for mosquitoes go, as we
found them in the summer.

We covered all of the territory on both sides of
the river where we have suits pending and investigated both
the conditions around the houses and conditions in the reser-
voir.

One thing which I was glad to note was that there
are now a considerable number of minnows in the reservoir;
just how numerous they are I am unable to say, but partic-
ularly around Ida, which is a railroad station on the
L. & N., I noticed a good many. This was particularly inter-
esting, after my experience at the Shrader's mill pond where
I was unable to find a single one.

Mr. Van Dine, of the Bureau of Entomology, has been
here and is also going to supply us with top minnows for
stocking the reservoir and for breeding purposes. He went
over the reservoir and is giving the matter study now and
will advise us what he proposes to do sometime in the near
future.

FRANK S. WASHBURN,
PRESIDENT

J. W. WORTHINGTON, VICE-PRESIDENT
F. H. CHAMBERLAIN, GEN'L. MGR.

THOS. W. MARTIN, GEN. COUNSEL
WILEY ALFORD, SEC'Y & TREAS.

ALABAMA POWER COMPANY
BIRMINGHAM, ALABAMA.

Concerning your survey, I am somewhat uncertain as
to the best place to conduct this, as I presume you are
anxious to get prompt results. I think that possibly it
might be worth while to consider a survey above Lock 5 on
the Coosa River. This dam is now under construction and
should be completed sometime this year. It was only 14 feet
high and will not flood out a large amount of territory, and
for this reason I presume that results will not be as satis-
factory to you as if it was a higher dam and a larger reser-
voir to survey.

If you do not think it worth while to consider
this, possibly the area above Lock 18 on the Coosa River
would be sorth considering. It is almost impossible to say
when the Lock 18 will be constructed. This is the one which
we wanted to start construction on in 1912 for the purpose
of establishing a fertilizer plant at Montgomery, but we
were not permitted to do this on account of the veto of
President Taft.

Personally, I do not believe that this project
will be started as soon as the Muscle Shoals project, but
the Muscle Shoals project will take five years to construct,
and possibly in that interval this dam may be started and
completed.

If you consider going into any one of these sites
with investigations and there is anything which we can do to
assist you, we will be very glad to do it.

We have topographical plans of Muscle Shoals and
of Lock 18, but we have no topography of Lock 5; however,
you can get that from the War Department.

I notice from LePrince's report that there are
quite a number of questions still open relating to breeding
in the summer months.

Doubtless you are familiar with the fact that the
Lock 17 dam on the Black Warrior River was recently completed
FRANK S. WASHBURN,
PRESIDENT
J. W. WORTHINGTON, VICE-PRESIDENT
F. H. CHAMBERLAIN, GEN'L. MGR.
THOS. W. MARTIN, GEN. COUNSEL
WILEY ALFORD, SEC'Y & TREAS.
ALABAMA POWER COMPANY
BIRMINGHAM, ALABAMA.
#3 H.R.C. 2/17/1915/
and the reservoir now covers over 10,000 acres. Possibly
if you are anxious to get information on the breeding of
the reservoir in the summer months of its first year, this
may be a good place to go for this information. No clearing
was done on this reservoir by the Federal Government.

I have a great deal of interest in this work which
you are conducting and believe that results are already be-
ginning to show from this agitation concerning the cause of
malaria. The other day when we were driving through the
country there were several instances where the better class
of farmers had constructed ditches and drained pools close to
their houses. Practically all the houses still remain
unscreened, but possibly by the summer season there may be
some progress along these lines.

After these several months experience in investi-
gating conditions around our reservoir, and I presume these
conditions are typical for a great part of the State, I
believe that the lack of progress among our farmers can be
attributed more to malaria than to anything else. In fact,
these 700 people who have sued us have been having malaria
for years, or they would not have sued us at all, as they would
have had ambition enough to get out and hustle for a living
by farming or some other means.

I certainly hope that you can see your way clear
to conduct an active campaign against malaria in this State
and that sufficient money will be apportioned to you for
this purpose.

I notice from the papers that our Chamber of Com-
merce and other civic organizations throughout the State
are giving a great deal of time and attention to crop diver-
sification and other matters of interest to the farmers; but
it seems to me that matters like that are automatically
looked after and, if you can direct the attention of these
organizations to your work they can do a thousand times more
good working on this subject than they can working along
the lines on which they are now working.

FRANK S. WASHBURN,
PRESIDENT

J. W. WORTHINGTON, VICE-PRESIDENT
F. H. CHAMBERLAIN, GEN'L. MGR.

THOS. W. MARTIN, GEN. COUNSEL
WILEY ALFORD, SEC'Y & TREAS.

ALABAMA POWER COMPANY
BIRMINGHAM, ALABAMA.

I could write all day on this subject with pleas-
ure, but presume I have imposed on you by expressing opinions
on a subject with which I have so little familiarity.
div1.closer: Yours very truly, BR Newton OGT:LF
